SENT.plain: The incidence of convulsion and associated factors were retrospectively analyzed in 23 patients with symptomatic cerebral vasospasm following subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) who underwent a total of 31 intra-arterial infusion of fasudil hydrochloride (IAFH) procedures in 49 vessels
Fasudil hydrochloride was administered by superselective infusion via a microcatheter positioned at the proximal portion of the affected artery
Thirteen procedures were performed by manually controlled infusion of 30-75 mg fasudil hydrochloride (1.2-3.75 mg/ml) for approximately 10 minutes
Eighteen procedures were performed by continuous infusion of 60 mg fasudil hydrochloride (1.2 mg/ml) by infusion pump at a constant rate of 3 mg/min
Neurological improvement was observed after 18 of 22 procedures in patients with neurological deterioration due to vasospasm
Convulsion during IAFH developed in 4 patients, all treated by manual infusion (p < 0.05)
The manual infusion method (p < 0.05) and infusion rate greater than 3 mg/min (p < 0.01) were significantly associated with the incidence of convulsion during IAFH
IAFH was effective for treating cerebral vasospasm following aneurysmal SAH
IAFH at a constant rate of 3 mg/min delivered by infusion pump improved the symptoms of cerebral vasospasm and prevented convulsions during IAFH
